title: How to Clean a Mortar and Pestle: Easy Steps for Any Material

steps.title: Wipe the mortar and pestle with a paper towel.
steps.content: Wipe the mortar and pestle with a paper towel. Remove any leftover food residue inside the mortar with a clean paper towel. Then, wipe the pestle to clean off any debris, too.

steps.title: Wash the mortar and pestle with warm water and unscented dish soap.
steps.content: Wash the mortar and pestle with warm water and unscented dish soap . Wet a soft sponge or dishcloth with warm water and apply a squirt of unscented dish soap. Then, gently scrub the mortar and pestle to clean off any stubborn food residue. [1] X Research source Use an unscented dish soap to prevent the taste and smell of the soap from seeping into the marble. Note : Some mortar and pestle manufacturers don’t recommend using dish soap to clean marble mortar and pestles. Always follow the manufacturer’s guidelines to clean your mortar and pestle safely.

steps.title: Rinse the mortar and pestle and pat it dry.
steps.content: Rinse the mortar and pestle and pat it dry. Hold the mortar and pestle under warm running water to remove the soapy residue and any food debris you cleaned off. Then, wipe it with a clean kitchen towel and leave it to air dry on the cloth or a dish drying rack . [2] X Research source Flip the mortar and pestle over halfway through drying to ensure it dries completely before you put it away.

steps.title: Scrub the mortar and pestle with warm water and unscented dish soap.
steps.content: Scrub the mortar and pestle with warm water and unscented dish soap . Rinse leftover food debris on the mortar and pestle with warm running water. Then, squirt a few drops of unscented dish soap onto a firm and abrasive scrub brush . Use it to remove any stubborn and stuck-on food residue. [3] X Research source It may take a bit of elbow grease to scrub and work out all of the residue on the mortar and pestle. Scented dish soaps can potentially seep into the granite and leave behind a soapy aftertaste. So, stick to using an unscented formula. Note : Some manufacturers advise against cleaning granite mortar and pestles with dish soap and recommend just using water. Consult the instructions that came with your tool for the best way to wash it.

steps.title: Rinse the mortar and pestle and dry it with a clean towel.
steps.content: Rinse the mortar and pestle and dry it with a clean towel. Hold the mortar and pestle under warm running water to remove the soap and any debris you scrubbed off. Then, wipe it with a clean kitchen towel before you put it away. [4] X Research source If the mortar and pestle feels damp after patting it dry, leave it to air dry on a clean towel. Just turn it over a few times as it dries.

steps.title: Scrub the molcajete with warm water and a firm brush.
steps.content: Scrub the molcajete with warm water and a firm brush . Hold the molcajete and tejolote (the pestle-like tool) under warm water to rinse off any food residue. Then, use a firm kitchen brush to scrub off stuck-on debris. [5] X Research source Molcajetes are traditional Mexican kitchen tools that work similarly to mortar and pestles. They’re typically made out of volcanic rock. Note : Volcanic rock is very porous, so many manufacturers don’t recommend cleaning molcajetes with dish soap. The soap can get trapped in the stone and leave behind an unpleasant taste. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse and dry the molcajete.
steps.content: Rinse and dry the molcajete. Use warm water to rinse out the food residue you scrubbed off. Then, wipe the molcajete and tejolote with a clean kitchen towel. Lay it on its side on a clean cloth to air dry, making sure to rotate it about every 30 minutes so it dries completely. [7] X Research source Store your molcajete and tejolote once they’re both dry.

steps.title: Rinse the mortar and pestle with warm water.
steps.content: Rinse the mortar and pestle with warm water. Place your mortar and pestle under warm running water. Mendes advises to continue rinsing the pieces until a majority of the food debris is removed.

steps.title: Scrub the mortar and pestle with a brush or sponge.
steps.content: Scrub the mortar and pestle with a brush or sponge. If any stubborn residue is on the mortar and pestle, Mendes asserts that “scrubbing…should do the trick.” Just use a new and unused scrub brush or abrasive sponge to lift off stubborn and set-in food debris. Keep the scrub brush or sponge you use on the mortar and pestle separate from the cleaning brushes you use on dishes. Using separate tools prevents you from contaminating your mortar and pestle. Note : Most experts don’t recommend using dish soap for glass, metal, and ceramic mortar and pestles, either. The soap can seep into the material and leave a soapy smell or taste. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the mortar and pestle and pat it dry with a towel.
steps.content: Rinse the mortar and pestle and pat it dry with a towel. Make sure to rinse your mortar and pestle thoroughly with warm water to remove all of the debris. Then, wipe the pieces dry with a clean kitchen towel. [9] X Research source Alternatively, set your mortar and pestle on a drying rack or clean towel to air dry. Rotate or flip the pieces over to ensure they dry completely.

steps.title: Remove food debris with a dry paper towel.
steps.content: Remove food debris with a dry paper towel. Use a dry paper towel or scrub brush to wipe food debris off of your mortar and pestle. Just keep wiping until you remove most of the debris.

steps.title: Wipe the mortar and pestle with a damp cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the mortar and pestle with a damp cloth. Mendes doesn’t recommend submerging a wood mortar and pestle in water. Instead, she says to “wipe [it] with a damp cloth” until no more food residue comes off. Wring out any excess water from the towel before wiping your mortar and pestle. If your mortar and pestle are very dirty, rinse out the cloth between wipes. Submerging wood mortar and pestles in water can damage the material and cause it to warp.

steps.title: Let the mortar and pestle air dry.
steps.content: Let the mortar and pestle air dry. Mendes advises setting your mortar and pestle on a drying rack or clean kitchen towel to air dry. Flip the pieces a couple of times to ensure they’re completely dry on all sides.

steps.title: Apply a food-grade mineral oil.
steps.content: Apply a food-grade mineral oil . Mendes recommends wiping a wood mortar and pestle with mineral oil to “help keep it from drying out” and cracking. Just pour a small amount of oil onto a clean paper towel or cloth. Then, wipe the oil into your mortar and pestle. Food-grade mineral oil is odorless, tasteless, and will not spoil. [10] X Research source Make sure the mortar and pestle is completely dry before storing it.

steps.title: Grind uncooked white rice into all types of mortar and pestles.
steps.content: Grind uncooked white rice into all types of mortar and pestles. Pour 2 tbsp (22 g) of uncooked rice into the mortar. Then, Mendes says to use your pestle to roughly grind the rice into the mortar until it becomes a dark color. The rice acts as an abrasive and gets into the small grooves of the mortar, lifting up stubborn debris and removing odors. Repeat this process until the rice stays white. Remove the old rice powder, add 2 tbsp (22 g) of uncooked rice, and grind it into a powder. Make sure your mortar and pestle are completely dry before grinding rice with them.

steps.title: Wash mortar and pestles with unscented dish soap as an alternative.
steps.content: Wash mortar and pestles with unscented dish soap as an alternative. If using rice doesn’t get out the stains, clean the mortar and pestle with warm water, unscented dish soap, and a scrub brush or sponge. Using an unscented formula reduces the likelihood of leaving behind a soapy aftertaste or smell. [11] X Research source If you’re cleaning a wooden mortar and pestle, apply the soap onto a damp cloth. Then, wipe it into the mortar and pestle.

steps.title: Dab marble mortar and pestles with lemon juice or white vinegar.
steps.content: Dab marble mortar and pestles with lemon juice or white vinegar. For stubborn stains on marble, wet a dishcloth or cotton ball with lemon juice or white vinegar. Then, dab the cloth into the stain. Just keep wiping the spot until it is gone. [12] X Research source Warning : Do not soak marble mortar and pestles with acidic cleaners or leave them on for a long time. Acids can damage and even dissolve marble.

steps.title: Rinse and dry the mortar and pestle after treating stains.
steps.content: Rinse and dry the mortar and pestle after treating stains. Once the stain is gone, hold the mortar and pestle under warm water to rinse off the stain remover and any debris you removed. Then, pat the mortar and pestle dry with a towel or set it on a drying rack to air dry. Flip and rotate your mortar and pestle as it dries to ensure it’s completely dry before putting it away.
